**The Mysterious Azure Casket of Numinous Treasure: Scripture of the Gathering of the Profound**

**Scripture Title:** *The Mysterious Azure Casket of Numinous Treasure: Scripture of the Gathering of the Profound*
**Author:** Unknown
**Three Scrolls**
**Source Text:** *Daoist Canon of the Orthodox Unity*, *Great Mystery Section*

### *The Mysterious Azure Casket of Numinous Treasure: Scripture of the Gathering of the Profound, Scroll One*
**Section of the Crimson Clarity Unfolding the Diagram**

The celestial writ reveals the great Dao,
suddenly disclosing its root and source.
It governs with a fundamental principle,
converges upon an original essence.
Encompassing Heaven and Earth,
it penetrates the obscure and profound.
Yin and Yang pair in harmony,
the Way of Heaven unfolds naturally.

The Mysterious and the Yellow establish their positions,
then divide into two:
the light and pure ascend to cover the Earth,
the heavy and turbid descend to support Heaven.
The light and pure accumulate as qi,
transforming into clouds and mist.
The heavy and turbid accumulate as qi,
and water emerges from lofty sources.
When the singular qi transforms into water,
the *Kan* trigram is born.

- **Winter Solstice** (upper)
- **Summer Solstice** (upper)
- **Awakening of Insects** (upper)
- **White Dew** (upper)
- **Pure Brightness** (middle)
- **Cold Dew** (middle)
- **Beginning of Summer** (middle)
- **Beginning of Winter** (middle)

The *Kan* trigram arises at *zi*,
the place where Yang qi first stirs.
All things begin to move,
sprouts gradually flourish.
Heaven begins to spread its Yang qi,
and humans advance in their constant Way.
To divine for a person:
when one seeks to initiate new affairs, this is the beginning.
*Kan* is the center of Heaven and Earth,
movement as if midway on the path.
Only when the stars are prosperous and the gates aligned
can matters be accomplished.

The second qi is Earth,
linked with the terrestrial realm.
Within water, Yang gathers,
forming mountains, stones, cities, and rivers.
Yin and Yang intertwine,
and the spirit of the *Kun* trigram is complete.
Beneath the clouds and mist,
above the earth and stone,
Yin essence congeals,
while Yang ascends and advances.

- **Lesser Cold** (upper)
- **Lesser Heat** (upper)
- **Beginning of Spring** (lower)
- **Beginning of Autumn** (lower)
- **Grain Rain** (middle)
- **Frost Descent** (middle)
- **Lesser Fullness** (middle)
- **Lesser Snow** (middle)

The *Kun* trigram resides at *shen*,
the utmost Yin, most yielding.
*(Text incomplete: "First missing passage...")*
Mother of beginnings and endings,
obscuring movement and stillness.
*(Text incomplete: "No missing passage...")*
It can proceed but cannot halt,
can devise plans but cannot see their end.

The third qi is Wood,
sprouting forth from the Earth.
The *Zhen* trigram holds its proper position.

- **Greater Cold** (upper)
- **Greater Heat** (upper)
- **Spring Equinox** (upper)
- **Autumn Equinox** (upper)
- **Rain Water** (lower)
- **End of Heat** (upper)
- **Grain in Ear** (middle)
- **Greater Snow** (middle)

The *Zhen* trigram arises at *mao*,
its thunderous might forging strength.
*Zhen* is movement,
and movement brings forth radiance,
gradually advancing with the benefit of nurturing winds,
enhancing growth and transformation.
Alternating flourishing and decline,
mutually dependent in their ebb and flow.
To divine for a person:
when one acts with plans and encounters others,
it is also called the Gate of Thunder.
In all matters, meeting the Ascending Gate brings surprise,
yet one has not yet entered its inner chamber.
Only when the stars are prosperous and the gates aligned
can all affairs be accomplished.

The fourth qi is the *Xun* trigram,
ordering the myriad things.
Wind moves within,
lightning flashes with fierce brilliance.

- **Winter Solstice** (lower)
- **Summer Solstice** (lower)
- **Awakening of Insects** (lower)
- **White Dew** (lower)
- **Pure Brightness** (upper)
- **Cold Dew** (upper)
- **Beginning of Summer** (upper)
- **Beginning of Winter** (upper)

The *Xun* trigram engenders at *si*,
termed the Four Voids—
where the hundred rivers overflow,
all returning to it.
When the great departs and the small arrives,
Heaven and Earth have not yet conjoined,
yet the myriad things first intermingle.
Yin and Yang have already merged,
yet the qi of the trigrams remains unaligned.
What first takes form flourishes,
while what has already sprouted fails to grow.
To divine for a person:
one may act before or after,
affairs reach their inception
but are obstructed at their sprouting.
The trigram’s image is vast—
even rivers and seas return to it.
In all matters, one should seek the mean as an omen.

The Hundred Spirits first take form,
the Central Five Qi.
Heaven first covers... [text corrupt]
the Five Qi intermingling,
humankind begins here.

- **Minor Cold** (lower)
- **Minor Heat** (lower)
- **Beginning of Spring** (middle)
- **Beginning of Autumn** (middle)
- **Grain Rain** (upper)
- **Frost’s Descent** (upper)
- **Grain in Ear** (upper)
- **Minor Snow** (upper)

The Canon states: The central image is void,
referring to the position of *wu* and *ji*.
Earth is lodged in *Kun*,
borne by the Mother.
The myriad things obtain it to live,
governed by it to grow.
When mountains and rivers take shape,
the Hundred Spirits first emerge.
The numbers of Heaven and Earth—
five times five makes twenty-five,
completing the Great Dao
and activating the spirits.
The Six Qi are vigorous and bright,
firm and yielding each in its place.
The myriad things all flourish,
Yin and Yang greatly prosper.
The hundred vessels first open,
*Qian* and *Kun* radiate splendor.

- **Major Cold** (lower)
- **Major Heat** (lower)
- **Spring Equinox** (lower)
- **Autumn Equinox** (lower)
- **Rain Water** (middle)
- **End of Heat** (middle)
- **Grain in Beard** (upper)
- **Major Snow** (upper)

The *Qian* hexagram generates *Hai*,
where Yin qi reaches its extreme.
Thus, in the Dao of transformation,
when the decisive moment comes, Yin must retreat,
and pure Yang begins to arise—
this is the meaning of the small departing and the great arriving.
Metal and Water interflow,
directly generating through greatness.
Thus, *Qian* in stillness is focused,
in movement is single-minded.
The firmness of Heaven inclines above,
and the sun and moon return to it.
When divining human fortune or misfortune,
the signs are half in hesitation, cycling endlessly—
proceeding thus, there must be breaks and omissions.
Metal qi lacks support,
and the force of withering arrives.
Unwittingly, a chill descends,
and the hexagram emerges from *Dui*.

None escape the seventh,
as Heaven and Earth startle in smoke.

- **Winter Solstice** (middle)
- **Summer Solstice** (middle)
- **Awakening of Insects** (middle)
- **White Dew** (middle)
- **Pure Brightness** (middle)
- **Cold Dew** (lower)
- **Beginning of Summer** (lower)
- **Beginning of Winter** (lower)

The *Dui* hexagram generates *You*,
where the gate of the moon is tied.
The setting sun wanes and declines,
and the myriad things age and die.
It enforces the withering command,
hence called the place where Heaven and Earth reward good and punish evil.
*Dui* means joy.
When divining, one may encounter disputes or lawsuits,
unable to clarify reason—
the schemes of the secretive will be exposed.
It is also the gate of the sun and moon,
so all matters will be obstructed in the end.

*Gen* halts at eight,
where the myriad things harbor destruction.
Fire emerges in *Yin*,
forging the seven metals.
Looking down, one sees the pit of *Kan*;
gazing up, the brightness of *Li*.

- **Minor Cold** (middle)
- **Minor Heat** (middle)
- **Beginning of Spring** (upper)
- **Beginning of Autumn** (upper)
- **Grain Rain** (lower)
- **Frost’s Descent** (lower)
- **Lesser Fullness** (lower)
- **Minor Snow** (lower)

The *Gen* hexagram arises in *Yin*,
where advance and retreat know no constancy.
When it is time to halt, halt;
when it is time to move, move.
In motion and stillness, one does not miss the proper moment—
*Gen* means halting where one ought to halt.
When divining, one’s advance or retreat
will not depart from one’s dwelling.
In the month of *Jianyin*,
the yang qi greatly extends.
One may advance but must not retreat—
this is the time to press forward.
Fire blazes above,
water moistens below.
Within their interplay,
day and night are divided.
At night, the yang ascends ninefold,
inverting and transforming all.

- **Major Cold** (middle)
- **Major Heat** (middle)
- **Spring Waters** (middle)
- **Autumn Equinox** (upper)
- **Rain Water** (middle)
- **End of Heat** (lower)
- **Grain in Ear** (lower)
- **Major Snow** (lower)

The *Li* hexagram arises in *Wu*,
where yin qi is born.
The yang qi divides its position,
and the two encroach upon each other.
The firm resides without,
yet can remain settled;
the yielding lies within,
yet cannot fix its place.
The great departs, the small arrives—
brightness yet [lacuna].
When [lacuna] is exhausted,
affairs will perish.
When divining, one may encounter unrighteous principles.
Aligning qi and transcending spirit,
one relies on the eight trigrams of the palace.
Splitting and uniting, waxing and waning,
rising and falling alternate.
North and south traverse,
forming winter and summer;
east and west emerge and submerge,
dividing day and night.
The sun and moon cycle endlessly,
never failing to meet in due course.

Heaven is *Qian*, father of the myriad sounds;
Earth is *Kun*, mother of the myriad things.
When yin qi has waned,
*Xun* becomes the eldest daughter.
It weaves through the nine voids,
encompassing the eight lands,
aligning the seven luminaries,
and returning to the Purple Tenuity.
It binds the warp of Heaven and Earth,
the stars and sun follow the turning jade.
The pivot is fixed in *Kan*,
the Dipper’s handle points high.
The ten thousand forms array in order—
Heaven’s rigidity directs the lunar generals.
Day and night divide swift and slow.
The yellow, red, and black paths
follow the shortness of the *Kui*.
The ten thousand forms hang in display,
encircling and guarding the imperial enclosure.
The four poles establish the great luminaries,
the four seasons are woven by their warp and weft.

The Eastern Palace of the Great Sun Sovereign,
Jupiter in the Celestial Palace of *Tianpeng*.
The Azure Spring governs the south;
Mars, the Earth-Water Palace, *Luoshu* and *Tianyou*.
The Vermilion Summer governs the west,
overseeing the middle realm—
the Moon, Venus, Saturn, Venus again,
*Ketu*, *Moon Comet*, and *Black Killer*.
The White Autumn governs the north;
Mercury, the Dark Warrior of the deep.
The Black Winter governs—
the twenty-eight lodgings:
*Jiao, Kang, Di, Fang, Xin, Wei, Ji, Dou, Niu, Nü, Xu, Wei, Shi, Bi, Kui, Lou, Wei, Mao, Bi, Zi, Shen, Jing, Gui, Liu, Xing, Zhang, Yi, Zhen*.
Beyond their circuit lie the thirty-six secondary luminaries.

The August Supreme Purity,
the primal script of the empty ultimate.
From the radiant brush’s movement,
the plain and unchanging unfolds.
The chariot ascends the cliff,
resolving filial reverence and profound reflection.

The Celestial Cloud’s Azure Pearl,
the radiant blossoms gleam in emptiness.
The Hall of Auspicious Longevity,
soaring illumination descends upon the sun.
In due season, all stars harmonize and assist,
the Five Phases and four cardinal directions.
They govern the qi and the fortunes of the age,
the rise and fall of humanity.
Regulating yin and yang,
eternal order may thus be anticipated.

**Thunder, Wind, and Rain Division**
The Great Unity’s thunder,
linked to the Eight Trigrams.
Heavenly Impulse shatters the armies;
the Thunder Ancestor, the Great Emperor.
When the movement enters the Qian Palace,
it is called the Opening of Heaven.
When it enters the Kun Palace,
it is called the Closing of Earth.
When it enters the Xun Palace,
it is named the Master of Wind.
When it enters the Kan Palace,
it is named the Master of Rain.
When it enters the Gen Palace,
it is named Mount Fan.
When it enters the Dui Palace,
it is named Overturned Waters.
When it enters the Zhen Palace,
it is named □□.
When it enters the Li Palace,
it is named the Convergence of Lightning.

There is also the Wounding Gate,
the Thunder Deity in direct service.
In Qian, the thunderbolt;
in □, □□.
On high, lightning flashes;
in Kan, rain arises.
In Dui, it severs things;
in Zhen, it strikes men.
In Kun and Gen,
□□□□.

Further, when in exaltation or prosperity,
the yang agent soars high.
When in decline or imprisonment,
the yin agent’s power wanes, low and faint.
After the turning of the seasons,
when □□□,
yin and yang alternate between brightness and obscurity,
prefiguring the celestial mechanism.

Earthly qi ascends,
clouds form in the void like celestial script.
The numbers of generation and completion
precede the *Hetu*.
Gui divides into ten exhaustions;
yin begins with thirteen origins.
Zi, Chou, Si, Wu,
Jia Shen adds Ji Wei—
the azure and yellow qi
reside in maternal nurturance,
released and dispersed in Qian.
Yi and Ding emerge from Zhen;
Ren Wu aligns at the shoulder.
Bing and Xin govern Xu and Hai,
the source of Dui’s marshes.
Mao and You are the gates of sun and moon;
Gen is the pivot of the door.
Geng Chen roams the upper trigram;
Wing’s fire star blazes,
its path traversing the Black Road,
luminous and perfectly round.

Further, when celestial qi descends,
the primordial constellation of the Southern Asterism
presides over the Bureau of Wind and Rain.
Next, its two envoys:
the Wind Master moves in reverse through the branches,
the Rain Master proceeds in order through the seasons,
both subordinate to the element of Water.
When wind arises in the moon,
fire scatters metal;
wood halts the sun;
earth subtly restrains wood.
Metal’s void mists metal and water;
when clouds lower, water and fire rage greatly,
the moon’s waters drip and flow.

The Great Yin’s solitary luminary
traverses the Black Road.
Heaven enacts its full mechanism,
the balance entering the Thunder Bureau.
Before the assembly of all spirits,
there is either rain or darkness.
When the Moon Bird’s spirit converges,
the balance enters Wei,
descending only into obscurity and confusion.
If encountering celestial stars,
the wind, water, and fire deities return to the four cardinal directions—
fierce winds snap trees,
mountains and peaks crumble and shatter.

When hoping for clear skies,
yin descends and yang ceases;
yang descends and yin vanishes.
Only through the Southern Asterism’s palace of control
does radiant clarity appear at once.
If the phases generate one another,
or if like kinds approach their mothers,
clouds gather and thicken,
darkening the empty sky.

Further to be avoided:
when Venus and Mars appear together,
or when azure and vermilion share the same position,
the moon traverses the Black Road—
then wind and thunder reverse and arise.
When the Great Yin aligns with You,
the wind rages unabated;
when rain arrives,
the Great Yin aligns with Mao—
rain gives birth to violent thunder,
rolling thunder shakes the rain.
When the Great Yin traverses the Mansion of Net,
dust flies and soil scatters.
When the Moon’s course reaches the Mansion of Winnowing Basket,
and the Great Yin departs from the Mansion of Net,
wind stirs the Celestial Minister.
If it leaves the Mansion of Winnowing Basket,
rain emerges from the celestial mechanism—
wind is the flourishing qi of yin and yang.

The Celestial Storehouse and Celestial Sameness
are the places where wind perishes.
The Celestial Beam and Celestial Pivot
are the vast domains of wind.
The Celestial Minister and Celestial Mechanism
are the officers who govern wind and rain.
The sun and moon’s movements
also pass through Qian and Kan.
Divided between two paths,
only the Black Road governs wind.
Emerging from the Nine Earths,
it appears and vanishes without trace.

The profound mystery of the Essential Mystery
divides between summer and winter.
The Thunder Bureau
has major and minor divisions.
The major division is the Bureau;
the minor division is the Palace.
Entering the Bureau governs rain;
entering the Palace governs wind.
The celestial mechanism resides in the sun,
□□□□.
Seeking the root and tracing the source,
transformation and evasion interpenetrate.
Three returns of day and night,
water and fire attack one another.
Three essentials of movement and stillness,
□□□□.
Direct service and hidden resonance
discuss the sun’s true lineage.
The two preceding and following celestial bodies
first descend within it.
The natural Dao
does not □□□.
Once yin and yang are divided,
the reckoning of wind and rain concludes.

**Nine August Sovereigns and Direct Talismans Division**
In the first configuration of the Yang Evasion,
on Bing or Xin days during the Wu Zi hour,
take Jia Shen’s Heavenly Impulse as the Direct Talisman,
adding it to Yi Palace’s six Wu’s Heavenly Penetrator hour.
Majestic are the Nine August Ones,
the Direct Talismans of the Nine Palaces.
They govern the primal qi,
transforming without end.

Each nature has its constancy, and all affairs submit to it.
Heavenly Penetrator’s Zi Qin
ensures enduring stability.
Water disasters and fire thefts—
none more dire in their omen.
For border pacification,
fortifying walls and piling earth,
or journeys of a thousand li,
these are ill-suited.
To establish camps and build strongholds,
Heavenly Penetrator is unfavorable.
In spring and summer, employ it—
military might roars.
For weddings or executions of noble wives,
burials bring prosperity.
In autumn and winter,
harvests dwindle for the lord.
Construction brings misfortune,
flames scorch the sky.
If divining a long absence,
a thousand li will see your return.

Heavenly Inner’s Zi Cheng—
its talisman and time-stem both align with the Heavenly Inner hour.
Revering the Dao above,
transmitting lineage and forging bonds,
harmony prevails.
If plotting unrighteous deeds,
curses and pestilence strike.
Marching to war or beheading generals,
men and horses meet no success.
For weddings or construction,
autumn and winter are favorable.
Relocation brings misfortune,
officials and thieves attack in tandem.
Two hundred li of calamity—
spring and summer bring their meeting.
Travelers return,
rain and mist shroud the way.

Heavenly Impulse’s Zi Qiao
avenges grievances and restores honor.
In war, great victory—
extraordinary merit is established.
Breaking sieges and assaulting enemies,
resentments dissolve.
In spring and summer, merchants
profit abundantly.
For those relocating or losing daughters,
within a year.
Those who undertake construction
meet misfortune within three years.
Brides die in childbirth,
grooms fall into hardship.
For official posts and martial affairs,
divine Heavenly Impulse.

The star of Heavenly Assistance,
named Zi Qing.
Establishing rites and cultivating teachings,
guarding the Dao and securing the self.
Deploying troops a thousand li,
might illuminates the northern court.
For official posts and martial affairs,
construction brings auspicious omens.
Marriages and relocations—
in spring and summer, joy abounds.
In autumn and winter, thieves and bandits
must not be confronted.
For military campaigns or commerce,
all affairs fail.

Heavenly Bird resides at the center,
sacrifices and prayers seek blessings.
In battle, divine aid—
its virtue named Zi Gong.
Pursuing vengeance and suppressing rebels,
success is never empty.
Autumn and winter bring great fortune,
spring and summer, frequent misfortune.
For marriages, commerce, and burials,
prosperity is especially profound.
Official posts bring great fortune,
all four seasons harmonious.

Qian Palace’s Zi Xiang
treats illness and seeks spirits.
Leading troops to great victory,
the star of the Sun and Heavenly Heart.
Seeking □□□,
encountering the utmost truth.
Spring and summer are unfavorable,
autumn and winter bring kindness.

Heavenly Pillar’s Zi Shen
conceals form and hides traces.
□□□□,
unfavorable for military campaigns.
Men wounded, horses dead,
chariot wheels broken.
Secret schemes and hidden plots—
without peril, there is smooth passage.
□□□□,
celebrations and felicitations reach fulfillment.
In battle, great victory—
the star of the Sun and Heavenly Task.
Marriages birth noble sons,
commerce brings wealth.
□□□□ ensures peace and tranquility.

Zi Fang’s direct hour—
long journeys bring joy.
Summoning harmony achieves success,
the star of the Sun and Heavenly Hero.
Deploying troops or waging battle,
soldiers suffer losses.
Do not speak of relocation—
firelight arises.
Building camps or constructing halls,
waists and eyes groan in pain.
When the weak follow the strong,
disaster strikes deeply.
Heaven’s numbers govern this—
all must revere and honor.

**Eight Trigrams’ Direct Affairs Division**
The eight gates’ direct affairs
divide by reversal and sequence.
Qian’s virtue opens,
its governance belongs to Metal.
For undertakings and games of chance,
great fortune in distant expeditions.

Kan Palace’s Resting Water—
all affairs must be clear.
Construction favors advancement,
seeking harmony and deploying troops.
Private schemes fulfill desires,
friendly gains in military campaigns.

Gen’s Mountainous Succession—
planning and initiating affairs.
Unfavorable for invasion,
favorable for visiting nobles.
In battle, defeat—
suffering Heaven’s punishment instead.

Zhen’s Injury governs—
assistance and execution bring satisfaction.
Suppressing traitors and capturing bandits,
seizing them mid-journey.
Auspicious actions employed,
yet calamity remains.

Xun’s spirit blocks and seals,
punishing errors and fleeing.
A hundred fail for every one that succeeds,
encountering evil men on the path.
The brilliance of Jing—
submitting memorials and presenting petitions.
Also favorable for □ formations,
also favorable for Xun’s troops.
Auspicious actions follow the middle way,
lost items harm the spirit.

Kun’s corner receives death—
punishment of annihilation.
Unfavorable for going out or coming in,
illness and disease arise together.
If undertaking auspicious affairs,
men quarrel and wealth is contested.

Dui’s Beam and Surprise Gate—
ambushes and captures bring satisfaction.
Breaking sieges and attacking enemies,
others perish while we survive.
The weak follow the strong,
changing with the trigram’s shifts.
Reversal brings calamity,
urgency brings punishment.
When the day’s stem visits the trigram,
Heavenly Unity’s spirit—
Metal transforms and Water is born,
Water flows and Wood flourishes.
Wood stirs and Fire blazes,
Fire flames and Earth levels.
Earth’s essence and Metal grows,
above and below mutually sustain.
Thus, fortune is attained,
and all enjoys smooth passage.

Metal stirs and Wood breaks,
Wood stirs and Earth sprouts.
Earth stirs and Water extinguishes,
Water stirs and Fire turns to dust.
Fire stirs and Metal is flawed—
this is called reversal.
The son leads the father,
the younger brother presents his elder.
With Water obtaining Water,
ministers overstep their lord.
With Water obtaining Earth,
documents and official punishments.
With Earth obtaining Water,
talent and fortune contend.
With Wood obtaining Metal,
quarrels arise.
With Metal obtaining Fire,
perversity against human nature.
With Fire obtaining Water,
loss of □□□.

When talismanic affairs align,
whether lord or minister.
If the lord harms the minister,
worthies are cut off.
If the minister betrays the lord,
□□□□.
When lord and minister rejoice in meeting,
they mount chariots and ascend the clouds.

**Yin-Yang Transformation Division**
In the Great Beginning’s undifferentiated unity,
yin and yang delight in each other.
Thus, comet obstructions arise,
regrets and adversities diverge.
Obstructions flourish then wither,
the Azure Dragon turns its head.
Tombs collapse and flying crows,
Qian and Zhen block death.
Misfortune exists, fortune is absent—
stars and gates follow their sequence.
Proclaiming and grasping authority,
the White Tiger flees in rebellion.
Trapped wealth and the Dragon’s flight,
Kun’s height overturns them.
Affairs in decline and decay,
deploying troops brings illness.
Residents do not endure,
reckless words from the Vermilion Bird.
Worry over thieves and the victorious Snake,
positions divided between Qian and Xun.
Documents intersect,
surprise and worry breed suspicion.
Drawing in others,
affairs are often unreal.
Empty reputations and boasts—
two stars enter each other.
The Heavenly Gate at Gen’s corner—
governs strife.
Affairs delay and obstruct,
Metal enters affairs.
Treachery leads to loss,
the sovereign hesitates further.
Fire enters and retreats,
great punishments fly and hide.

Disaster and chaos from war’s □,
□□ must flee north.
Raising the body beyond bounds,
bandits and foes stand face to face.
Do not leave home—
official calamity and illness arrive.
Wealth collapses, plans go awry,
the Celestial Sovereign enters the White.
Disaster strikes the honored position,
affairs arise from within,
movement brings harm and error.
If war is spoken of,
the general will surely lose his home.
Venus enters Yi—
outer stillness, calamity and exhaustion.
When the Gate meets Venus,
those parted will reunite.
When Venus enters the Gate,
those united will separate.
Encountering it on the battlefield,
the army’s general loses his might.
Fortune and misfortune, survival and ruin—
to examine human affairs,
observe the patterns: as the pattern is, so is the response.
Follow the pattern to clarify.
Divining affairs, scrutinize Geng,
the year, month, day, and hour.
If meeting the Flying Stem,
joy lifts the brows.
If meeting the Hidden Pattern,
all matters reach fulfillment.
The year governs parents,
the month, siblings and kin.
The day governs oneself,
the hour, wife and children.
If divining loss,
follow the category to know the time.
When the hour is patterned, seize it in the hour;
when the year is patterned, pursue it in the year.
When the day is patterned, gain it on the day—
without pattern, the Three Auspicious remain.
When the tally conflicts with Mars,
vexation and trouble breed chaos.
When the Gate is adverse, the host loses;
schemes and rebellion invite mockery.
When the day or hour meets the Comet’s pattern,
affairs must guard against danger.
Darkness and obscurity connect—
thieves and bandits yet hold back.
When punishment and virtue gather,
movement and stillness follow the auspicious.
Transformations are endless,
Yang tally in Yang time.
Meeting an auspicious Gate,
all affairs may proceed.
When the tally is Yin and the general weak,
nothing is favorable.
With the auspicious but no Gate,
hardship arises within.
With the Gate but no auspicious,
the journey turns back midway.
Returning chants and hidden chants—
affairs are marked by doubt.
When Heaven and Earth unite,

### *The Mysterious Azure Casket of Numinous Treasure: Scripture of the Gathering of the Profound, Scroll One*
**Section of the Crimson Clarity Unfolding the Diagram**

The celestial writ reveals the great Dao,
suddenly disclosing its root and source.
It governs with a fundamental principle,
converges upon an original essence.
Encompassing Heaven and Earth,
it penetrates the obscure and profound.
Yin and Yang pair in harmony,
the Way of Heaven unfolds naturally.

The Mysterious and the Yellow establish their positions,
then divide into two:
the light and pure ascend to cover the Earth,
the heavy and turbid descend to support Heaven.
The light and pure accumulate as qi,
transforming into clouds and mist.
The heavy and turbid accumulate as qi,
and water emerges from lofty sources.
When the singular qi transforms into water,
the *Kan* trigram is born.

- **Winter Solstice** (upper)
- **Summer Solstice** (upper)
- **Awakening of Insects** (upper)
- **White Dew** (upper)
- **Pure Brightness** (middle)
- **Cold Dew** (middle)
- **Beginning of Summer** (middle)
- **Beginning of Winter** (middle)

The *Kan* trigram arises at *zi*,
the place where Yang qi first stirs.
All things begin to move,
sprouts gradually flourish.
Heaven begins to spread its Yang qi,
and humans advance in their constant Way.
To divine for a person:
when one seeks to initiate new affairs, this is the beginning.
*Kan* is the center of Heaven and Earth,
movement as if midway on the path.
Only when the stars are prosperous and the gates aligned
can matters be accomplished.

The second qi is Earth,
linked with the terrestrial realm.
Within water, Yang gathers,
forming mountains, stones, cities, and rivers.
Yin and Yang intertwine,
and the spirit of the *Kun* trigram is complete.
Beneath the clouds and mist,
above the earth and stone,
Yin essence congeals,
while Yang ascends and advances.

- **Lesser Heat** (upper)
- **Beginning of Spring** (lower)
- **Beginning of Autumn** (lower)
- **Grain Rain** (middle)
- **Frost Descent** (middle)
- **Lesser Fullness** (middle)
- **Lesser Snow** (middle)

The *Kun* trigram resides at *shen*,
the utmost Yin, most yielding.
*(Text incomplete: "First missing passage...")*
Mother of beginnings and endings,
obscuring movement and stillness.
*(Text incomplete: "No missing passage...")*
It can proceed but cannot halt,
can devise plans but cannot see their end.

The third qi is Wood,
sprouting forth from the Earth.
The *Zhen* trigram holds its proper position.

- **Greater Heat** (upper)
- **Spring Equinox** (upper)

- **Rain Water** (lower)

*Zhen* is movement,
and movement brings forth radiance,
gradually advancing with the benefit of nurturing winds,
enhancing growth and transformation.
Alternating flourishing and decline,
mutually dependent in their ebb and flow.
To divine for a person:
when one acts with plans and encounters others,
it is also called the Gate of Thunder.
In all matters, meeting the Ascending Gate brings surprise,
yet one has not yet entered its inner chamber.
Only when the stars are prosperous and the gates aligned
can all affairs be accomplished.

The fourth qi is the *Xun* trigram,
ordering the myriad things.
Wind moves within,

- **White Dew** (lower)
- **Pure Brightness** (upper)
- **Cold Dew** (upper)
- **Beginning of Summer** (upper)

The *Qian* hexagram generates *Hai*,
where Yin qi reaches its extreme.
Thus, in the Dao of transformation,
when the decisive moment comes, Yin must retreat,
and pure Yang begins to arise—
this is the meaning of the small departing and the great arriving.
Metal and Water interflow,
directly generating through greatness.
Thus, *Qian* in stillness is focused,
in movement is single-minded.
The firmness of Heaven inclines above,
and the sun and moon return to it.
When divining human fortune or misfortune,
the signs are half in hesitation, cycling endlessly—
proceeding thus, there must be breaks and omissions.
Metal qi lacks support,
and the force of withering arrives.
Unwittingly, a chill descends,
and the hexagram emerges from *Dui*.

None escape the seventh,
as Heaven and Earth startle in smoke.

The *Dui* hexagram generates *You*,
where the gate of the moon is tied.
The setting sun wanes and declines,
and the myriad things age and die.
It enforces the withering command,
hence called the place where Heaven and Earth reward good and punish evil.
*Dui* means joy.
When divining, one may encounter disputes or lawsuits,
unable to clarify reason—
the schemes of the secretive will be exposed.
It is also the gate of the sun and moon,
so all matters will be obstructed in the end.

*Gen* halts at eight,
where the myriad things harbor destruction.
Fire emerges in *Yin*,
forging the seven metals.
Looking down, one sees the pit of *Kan*;
gazing up, the brightness of *Li*.

chunks.original_text: 艮卦生寅，谓进退无常。 时止则止，时行则行。 动静不失其时，艮者止止其所也。 占人进退，不离其居。 建寅之月，阳气大申。 可进不可退当遂也。 火炎于上，水润其下。 动静其中，分乎书夜。 夜阳九高，颠倒变化。 大寒中　　大暑中 春水中　　秋分上 雨水中　　处暑下 芒种下　　大雪下 离卦生午，阴气生焉。 阳气分位，相干犯也。 刚处其外，而能安居。 阴柔在外，而不能定分。 大往小来，明而□□。 □□既竭，事将亡矣。 占人当有不正之义。 接气超神，依宫八卦。 剎拆盈亏，乘除上下。 南北往来，以成冬夏。 东西出没，以分昼夜。 日月循环，不至交差。 乾为天兮，万吻之父。 坤为地兮，万物之母。 阴气既衰，巽为长女。 经纬九虚，总摄八土。 以齐七政，归於紫微，维纲天地，星日纵玑。 纽枢定坎，斗柄朝高。 森罗万象部 天刚指月将。 昼夜分速迟。 黄赤并黑道，永短从其魁。 森罗垂万象，环卫帝拱随。 四极立大曜，四时经纬推。 东方太阳帝君，岁星天宫天蓬。 青春主之南方，荧惑地水，宫罗天猷。 赤夏主之西方，统运中界，太阴后星，镇星太白，计都月孛黑杀。 白秋主之北方辰星，紫为玄武。 黑冬主之二十八宿：角、亢、氏、房、心、尾、箕、斗、牛、女、虚、危、室、壁、奎、娄、冑、昴、毕、觜、参、井、鬼、柳、星、张、翼、轸、虚外周围三十六曜。 皇太清玄，元文虚极。 由皓动翰，素无释变，奕车升崖，定孝重思，。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Gen* hexagram arises in *Yin*,
where advance and retreat know no constancy.
When it is time to halt, halt;
when it is time to move, move.
In motion and stillness, one does not miss the proper moment—
*Gen* means halting where one ought to halt.
When divining, one’s advance or retreat
will not depart from one’s dwelling.
In the month of *Jianyin*,
the yang qi greatly extends.
One may advance but must not retreat—
this is the time to press forward.
Fire blazes above,
water moistens below.
Within their interplay,
day and night are divided.
At night, the yang ascends ninefold,
inverting and transforming all.

- **Major Cold** (middle)
- **Major Heat** (middle)
- **Spring Waters** (middle)
- **Autumn Equinox** (upper)
- **Rain Water** (middle)
- **End of Heat** (lower)
- **Grain in Ear** (lower)
- **Major Snow** (lower)

The *Li* hexagram arises in *Wu*,
where yin qi is born.
The yang qi divides its position,
and the two encroach upon each other.
The firm resides without,
yet can remain settled;
the yielding lies within,
yet cannot fix its place.
The great departs, the small arrives—
brightness yet [lacuna].
When [lacuna] is exhausted,
affairs will perish.
When divining, one may encounter unrighteous principles.
Aligning qi and transcending spirit,
one relies on the eight trigrams of the palace.
Splitting and uniting, waxing and waning,
rising and falling alternate.
North and south traverse,
forming winter and summer;
east and west emerge and submerge,
dividing day and night.
The sun and moon cycle endlessly,
never failing to meet in due course.

Heaven is *Qian*, father of the myriad sounds;
Earth is *Kun*, mother of the myriad things.
When yin qi has waned,
*Xun* becomes the eldest daughter.
It weaves through the nine voids,
encompassing the eight lands,
aligning the seven luminaries,
and returning to the Purple Tenuity.
It binds the warp of Heaven and Earth,
the stars and sun follow the turning jade.
The pivot is fixed in *Kan*,
the Dipper’s handle points high.
The ten thousand forms array in order—
Heaven’s rigidity directs the lunar generals.
Day and night divide swift and slow.
The yellow, red, and black paths
follow the shortness of the *Kui*.
The ten thousand forms hang in display,
encircling and guarding the imperial enclosure.
The four poles establish the great luminaries,
the four seasons are woven by their warp and weft.

The Eastern Palace of the Great Sun Sovereign,
Jupiter in the Celestial Palace of *Tianpeng*.
The Azure Spring governs the south;
Mars, the Earth-Water Palace, *Luoshu* and *Tianyou*.
The Vermilion Summer governs the west,
overseeing the middle realm—
the Moon, Venus, Saturn, Venus again,
*Ketu*, *Moon Comet*, and *Black Killer*.
The White Autumn governs the north;
Mercury, the Dark Warrior of the deep.
The Black Winter governs—
the twenty-eight lodgings:
*Jiao, Kang, Di, Fang, Xin, Wei, Ji, Dou, Niu, Nü, Xu, Wei, Shi, Bi, Kui, Lou, Wei, Mao, Bi, Zi, Shen, Jing, Gui, Liu, Xing, Zhang, Yi, Zhen*.
Beyond their circuit lie the thirty-six secondary luminaries.

The August Supreme Purity,
the primal script of the empty ultimate.
From the radiant brush’s movement,
the plain and unchanging unfolds.
The chariot ascends the cliff,
resolving filial reverence and profound reflection.

chunks.original_text: 天昙碧珠，华曜空。 堂瑞广寿，飞照临日。 时诸星协赞，五行四维。 主张气运，人物兴衰。 调理阴阳，永世可期。 雷霆风雨部 太乙雷霆，八卦所系。 天冲破军，雷祖大帝。 运入乾宫，是为开天。 进入坤宫，是为阖地。 运入巽宫，名曰风师。 运入坎宫，名曰雨师。 运入艮官，名曰番山。 运入兑宫，名曰覆水。 运入震宫，名曰□□。 运入离宫，名曰电会。 又有伤门，直事雷神。 在乾霹雳，在□口□。 在高掣电，在坎雨兴。 在兑翦物，在震伐人。 在坤并艮，□□□□。 又推旺相，阳使高飞。 休囚阴使，势缓低微。 变化节后，遇□□□。 阴阳明晦，预合天机。 地气上升，云虚有篆。 生成之数，河图之先，癸分十尽，寅十三元。 子丑巳午，甲申加己未，青黄之气，存乎母育，发泄於乾。 乙丁出震，壬午齐肩。 丙辛戌亥，兑泽之源。 卯酉日月之门，艮为枢户。 庚辰游於高卦，翼火星炎，踱次黑道，皎洁光圆。 又推天气下降，混元之宿南辰，在治风雨司之。 次其二使，风逆循支。 雨师顺仲，同隶而为水。 风即发月，火即霏金，木即止日，土微微木。 金虚霭金水，云低水火大作，水月淋漓。 太阴一曜，躔次黑道。 天施全机，权衡入於雷府。 未会诸神，非雨则晦。 月禽神会，权衡入未，只降昏迷。 若遇天星，风水火二神归四正，猛风折木，山岳崩顽。 望晴阴降阳止，阳降阴灭。 只以南辰宫制，立见晴晖。 如乃相生，同类又有临交得母，转添云翳，黯黯空垂。 更忌太白荧惑，又见青朱同位，月躔黑道，返起风雷风到。 太阴同酉，风狂不弱雨到。 太阴同卯，雨生暴雷，轰雷震雨。 太阴躔於毕宿，扬尘播土。 月曜度到箕星，太阴离於毕宿，风起天相。 若别箕宿，雨出天机，风乃阴阳盛气。 天府天同，风之绝地。 天梁天枢，风之广位。 天相天机，司风雨吏。 日月之行，亦经高坎。 中分二道，唯黑主风。 出於九地，隐见无踪。 要玄之奥，分於夏冬。 雷霆之府，格有大小。 大格为府，小格为宫。 入府主雨，入宫主风。 天机在日，□□□□。 正根寻源，变遁而通。 三返昼夜，水火交攻。 三要动静，□□□□。 直事伏吟，论日真宗。 前后二辰，先降其中。 自然之道，不□□□。 阴阳一判，风雨数终。 九皇直符部 阳遁一局，丙辛日戊子时，以甲申天冲为直符，加乙宫六戊天蓬时。 巍巍九皇，直符九宫。 主张元气，变化无穷。

The Celestial Cloud’s Azure Pearl,
the radiant blossoms gleam in emptiness.
The Hall of Auspicious Longevity,
soaring illumination descends upon the sun.
In due season, all stars harmonize and assist,
the Five Phases and four cardinal directions.
They govern the qi and the fortunes of the age,
the rise and fall of humanity.
Regulating yin and yang,
eternal order may thus be anticipated.

**Thunder, Wind, and Rain Division**
The Great Unity’s thunder,
linked to the Eight Trigrams.
Heavenly Impulse shatters the armies;
the Thunder Ancestor, the Great Emperor.
When the movement enters the Qian Palace,
it is called the Opening of Heaven.
When it enters the Kun Palace,
it is called the Closing of Earth.
When it enters the Xun Palace,
it is named the Master of Wind.
When it enters the Kan Palace,
it is named the Master of Rain.
When it enters the Gen Palace,
it is named Mount Fan.
When it enters the Dui Palace,
it is named Overturned Waters.
When it enters the Zhen Palace,
it is named □□.
When it enters the Li Palace,
it is named the Convergence of Lightning.

There is also the Wounding Gate,
the Thunder Deity in direct service.
In Qian, the thunderbolt;
in □, □□.
On high, lightning flashes;
in Kan, rain arises.
In Dui, it severs things;
in Zhen, it strikes men.
In Kun and Gen,
□□□□.

Further, when in exaltation or prosperity,
the yang agent soars high.
When in decline or imprisonment,
the yin agent’s power wanes, low and faint.
After the turning of the seasons,
when □□□,
yin and yang alternate between brightness and obscurity,
prefiguring the celestial mechanism.

Earthly qi ascends,
clouds form in the void like celestial script.
The numbers of generation and completion
precede the *Hetu*.
Gui divides into ten exhaustions;
yin begins with thirteen origins.
Zi, Chou, Si, Wu,
Jia Shen adds Ji Wei—
the azure and yellow qi
reside in maternal nurturance,
released and dispersed in Qian.
Yi and Ding emerge from Zhen;
Ren Wu aligns at the shoulder.
Bing and Xin govern Xu and Hai,
the source of Dui’s marshes.
Mao and You are the gates of sun and moon;
Gen is the pivot of the door.
Geng Chen roams the upper trigram;
Wing’s fire star blazes,
its path traversing the Black Road,
luminous and perfectly round.

Further, when celestial qi descends,
the primordial constellation of the Southern Asterism
presides over the Bureau of Wind and Rain.
Next, its two envoys:
the Wind Master moves in reverse through the branches,
the Rain Master proceeds in order through the seasons,
both subordinate to the element of Water.
When wind arises in the moon,
fire scatters metal;
wood halts the sun;
earth subtly restrains wood.
Metal’s void mists metal and water;
when clouds lower, water and fire rage greatly,
the moon’s waters drip and flow.

The Great Yin’s solitary luminary
traverses the Black Road.
Heaven enacts its full mechanism,
the balance entering the Thunder Bureau.
Before the assembly of all spirits,
there is either rain or darkness.
When the Moon Bird’s spirit converges,
the balance enters Wei,
descending only into obscurity and confusion.
If encountering celestial stars,
the wind, water, and fire deities return to the four cardinal directions—
fierce winds snap trees,
mountains and peaks crumble and shatter.

When hoping for clear skies,
yin descends and yang ceases;
yang descends and yin vanishes.
Only through the Southern Asterism’s palace of control
does radiant clarity appear at once.
If the phases generate one another,
or if like kinds approach their mothers,
clouds gather and thicken,
darkening the empty sky.

Further to be avoided:
when Venus and Mars appear together,
or when azure and vermilion share the same position,
the moon traverses the Black Road—
then wind and thunder reverse and arise.
When the Great Yin aligns with You,
the wind rages unabated;
when rain arrives,
the Great Yin aligns with Mao—
rain gives birth to violent thunder,
rolling thunder shakes the rain.
When the Great Yin traverses the Mansion of Net,
dust flies and soil scatters.
When the Moon’s course reaches the Mansion of Winnowing Basket,
and the Great Yin departs from the Mansion of Net,
wind stirs the Celestial Minister.
If it leaves the Mansion of Winnowing Basket,
rain emerges from the celestial mechanism—
wind is the flourishing qi of yin and yang.

The Celestial Storehouse and Celestial Sameness
are the places where wind perishes.
The Celestial Beam and Celestial Pivot
are the vast domains of wind.
The Celestial Minister and Celestial Mechanism
are the officers who govern wind and rain.
The sun and moon’s movements
also pass through Qian and Kan.
Divided between two paths,
only the Black Road governs wind.
Emerging from the Nine Earths,
it appears and vanishes without trace.

The profound mystery of the Essential Mystery
divides between summer and winter.
The Thunder Bureau
has major and minor divisions.
The major division is the Bureau;
the minor division is the Palace.
Entering the Bureau governs rain;
entering the Palace governs wind.
The celestial mechanism resides in the sun,
□□□□.
Seeking the root and tracing the source,
transformation and evasion interpenetrate.
Three returns of day and night,
water and fire attack one another.
Three essentials of movement and stillness,
□□□□.
Direct service and hidden resonance
discuss the sun’s true lineage.
The two preceding and following celestial bodies

The natural Dao

**Nine August Sovereigns and Direct Talismans Division**
In the first configuration of the Yang Evasion,

adding it to Yi Palace’s six Wu’s Heavenly Penetrator hour.
Majestic are the Nine August Ones,
the Direct Talismans of the Nine Palaces.
They govern the primal qi,
transforming without end.

Each nature has its constancy, and all affairs submit to it.
Heavenly Penetrator’s Zi Qin
ensures enduring stability.
Water disasters and fire thefts—
none more dire in their omen.
For border pacification,
fortifying walls and piling earth,
or journeys of a thousand li,
these are ill-suited.
To establish camps and build strongholds,
Heavenly Penetrator is unfavorable.
In spring and summer, employ it—
military might roars.
For weddings or executions of noble wives,
burials bring prosperity.
In autumn and winter,
harvests dwindle for the lord.
Construction brings misfortune,
flames scorch the sky.
If divining a long absence,
a thousand li will see your return.

Heavenly Inner’s Zi Cheng—
its talisman and time-stem both align with the Heavenly Inner hour.
Revering the Dao above,
transmitting lineage and forging bonds,
harmony prevails.
If plotting unrighteous deeds,
curses and pestilence strike.
Marching to war or beheading generals,
men and horses meet no success.
For weddings or construction,
autumn and winter are favorable.
Relocation brings misfortune,
officials and thieves attack in tandem.
Two hundred li of calamity—
spring and summer bring their meeting.
Travelers return,
rain and mist shroud the way.

Heavenly Impulse’s Zi Qiao
avenges grievances and restores honor.
In war, great victory—
extraordinary merit is established.
Breaking sieges and assaulting enemies,
resentments dissolve.
In spring and summer, merchants
profit abundantly.
For those relocating or losing daughters,
within a year.
Those who undertake construction
meet misfortune within three years.
Brides die in childbirth,
grooms fall into hardship.
For official posts and martial affairs,
divine Heavenly Impulse.

The star of Heavenly Assistance,
named Zi Qing.
Establishing rites and cultivating teachings,
guarding the Dao and securing the self.
Deploying troops a thousand li,
might illuminates the northern court.
For official posts and martial affairs,
construction brings auspicious omens.
Marriages and relocations—
in spring and summer, joy abounds.
In autumn and winter, thieves and bandits
must not be confronted.
For military campaigns or commerce,
all affairs fail.

Heavenly Bird resides at the center,
sacrifices and prayers seek blessings.
In battle, divine aid—
its virtue named Zi Gong.
Pursuing vengeance and suppressing rebels,
success is never empty.
Autumn and winter bring great fortune,
spring and summer, frequent misfortune.
For marriages, commerce, and burials,
prosperity is especially profound.
Official posts bring great fortune,
all four seasons harmonious.

Qian Palace’s Zi Xiang
treats illness and seeks spirits.
Leading troops to great victory,
the star of the Sun and Heavenly Heart.
Seeking □□□,
encountering the utmost truth.
Spring and summer are unfavorable,
autumn and winter bring kindness.

Heavenly Pillar’s Zi Shen
conceals form and hides traces.
□□□□,
unfavorable for military campaigns.
Men wounded, horses dead,
chariot wheels broken.
Secret schemes and hidden plots—
without peril, there is smooth passage.
□□□□,
celebrations and felicitations reach fulfillment.
In battle, great victory—
the star of the Sun and Heavenly Task.
Marriages birth noble sons,
commerce brings wealth.
□□□□ ensures peace and tranquility.

Zi Fang’s direct hour—
long journeys bring joy.
Summoning harmony achieves success,
the star of the Sun and Heavenly Hero.
Deploying troops or waging battle,
soldiers suffer losses.
Do not speak of relocation—
firelight arises.
Building camps or constructing halls,
waists and eyes groan in pain.
When the weak follow the strong,
disaster strikes deeply.
Heaven’s numbers govern this—
all must revere and honor.

**Eight Trigrams’ Direct Affairs Division**
The eight gates’ direct affairs
divide by reversal and sequence.
Qian’s virtue opens,
its governance belongs to Metal.
For undertakings and games of chance,
great fortune in distant expeditions.

Kan Palace’s Resting Water—
all affairs must be clear.
Construction favors advancement,
seeking harmony and deploying troops.
Private schemes fulfill desires,
friendly gains in military campaigns.

Gen’s Mountainous Succession—
planning and initiating affairs.
Unfavorable for invasion,
favorable for visiting nobles.
In battle, defeat—
suffering Heaven’s punishment instead.

Zhen’s Injury governs—
assistance and execution bring satisfaction.
Suppressing traitors and capturing bandits,
seizing them mid-journey.
Auspicious actions employed,
yet calamity remains.

Xun’s spirit blocks and seals,
punishing errors and fleeing.
A hundred fail for every one that succeeds,
encountering evil men on the path.
The brilliance of Jing—
submitting memorials and presenting petitions.
Also favorable for □ formations,
also favorable for Xun’s troops.
Auspicious actions follow the middle way,
lost items harm the spirit.

Kun’s corner receives death—
punishment of annihilation.
Unfavorable for going out or coming in,
illness and disease arise together.
If undertaking auspicious affairs,
men quarrel and wealth is contested.

Dui’s Beam and Surprise Gate—
ambushes and captures bring satisfaction.
Breaking sieges and attacking enemies,
others perish while we survive.
The weak follow the strong,
changing with the trigram’s shifts.
Reversal brings calamity,
urgency brings punishment.
When the day’s stem visits the trigram,
Heavenly Unity’s spirit—
Metal transforms and Water is born,
Water flows and Wood flourishes.
Wood stirs and Fire blazes,
Fire flames and Earth levels.
Earth’s essence and Metal grows,
above and below mutually sustain.
Thus, fortune is attained,
and all enjoys smooth passage.

Metal stirs and Wood breaks,
Wood stirs and Earth sprouts.
Earth stirs and Water extinguishes,
Water stirs and Fire turns to dust.
Fire stirs and Metal is flawed—
this is called reversal.
The son leads the father,
the younger brother presents his elder.
With Water obtaining Water,
ministers overstep their lord.
With Water obtaining Earth,
documents and official punishments.
With Earth obtaining Water,
talent and fortune contend.
With Wood obtaining Metal,
quarrels arise.
With Metal obtaining Fire,
perversity against human nature.
With Fire obtaining Water,
loss of □□□.

When talismanic affairs align,
whether lord or minister.
If the lord harms the minister,
worthies are cut off.
If the minister betrays the lord,
□□□□.
When lord and minister rejoice in meeting,
they mount chariots and ascend the clouds.

**Yin-Yang Transformation Division**
In the Great Beginning’s undifferentiated unity,
yin and yang delight in each other.
Thus, comet obstructions arise,
regrets and adversities diverge.
Obstructions flourish then wither,
the Azure Dragon turns its head.
Tombs collapse and flying crows,
Qian and Zhen block death.
Misfortune exists, fortune is absent—
stars and gates follow their sequence.
Proclaiming and grasping authority,
the White Tiger flees in rebellion.
Trapped wealth and the Dragon’s flight,
Kun’s height overturns them.
Affairs in decline and decay,
deploying troops brings illness.
Residents do not endure,
reckless words from the Vermilion Bird.
Worry over thieves and the victorious Snake,
positions divided between Qian and Xun.
Documents intersect,
surprise and worry breed suspicion.
Drawing in others,
affairs are often unreal.
Empty reputations and boasts—
two stars enter each other.
The Heavenly Gate at Gen’s corner—
governs strife.
Affairs delay and obstruct,
Metal enters affairs.
Treachery leads to loss,
the sovereign hesitates further.
Fire enters and retreats,
great punishments fly and hide.

Heaven’s Rigid and Vast Fall—
all methods are held within.
Relying on the Rigid Dipper,
chant □□□.
Never act recklessly in the four seasons—
apply it as you will.
Avoiding illness, spirits, and ghosts,
besieged in battle.
Subduing the dark and obscure—
□□□□.
Overturn the Dipper, strike the Pass,
and recite the incantation:
*"Wondrous is the Dipper’s essence—twelve spirits,
step the Celestial Stem □□□.
□□ resembling shadows floating on azure clouds,
seven transformations stirring to ascend Yang brightness.
Knowing change brings fortune and misfortune,
passing the Dipper □□□ the Heavenly Pass.
Align with the statutes and commands of Jia and Yi,
tread the Heavenly Flower, ride the Heavenly Task,
embrace the Heavenly Pillar to reach the Heavenly Heart.
By this measure ascend the Heavenly Quail,
lean on the Heavenly Auxiliary, tread the Heavenly Impulse.
Enter the Heavenly Inner, exit the Heavenly Soaring,
the Dipper’s Way unites rigidity and softness.
Heaven’s blessings and emoluments endure ten thousand generations,
the clear and cold spring—why sink into the depths?
Entering the boundless for a thousand myriad years,
the Vast Fall spirits expel all filth.
A thousand ghosts and ten thousand spirits all perish,
burying their heads in the earth, motionless and inert.
Swiftly, swiftly, as the law of the Nine Emperor Stars of the Northern Dipper commands!"*

Majestic and vast, the *Great Crimson Jade Peak Prohibited Writ*—
a method not for the middle or lower realms to hear.
Though the text is transmitted orally,
the secret lies in Heaven’s transmission.
Profane and impure true writs
do not ascend to immortals’ ranks.
To recklessly transmit and confuse the vulgar—
the sin accumulates beyond measure.
To lightly reveal the mechanism—
calamity extends to the nine clans.
Only those of determined will should keep it secret.

**End of the First Scroll of the *Mysterious Essence Jade Casket Spirit Treasure Gathering Mystery Classic***

chunks.original_text: 太初肇判，三景开明。 九玄之中，清阳絪缊。 八景冥合，挺生六神。 光焕紫虚，郁流玉精。 分道散躯，六十之辰。 五行凝结，洞耀九宫。 金木水火土，变化雌雄。 分景散灵，千有八十。 出玄入微，洞达无穷。 气包天地，精冠太空。 能离能合，能阴能阳。 能上能下，能死能生。 能有能无，能成能败。 天无六甲，三光不明。 地无六甲，五岳不成。 人无六甲，不能保生。 遁而演之，妙道之根。 能通此灵，六合齐真。 用参天地，万法之门。 六气顺运，旋转十天。 六甲流布，局行幽冥。 甲子之祖，名曰桃平。 甲子之父，合景游并。 甲子之孙，曰王文卿。 甲戍之祖，名曰避方。 甲戌之父，刀兵万重。 甲戌之孙，曰展子江。 甲申之祖，名曰上盖张。 甲申之父，三会龙英。 甲申之孙，曰扈文长。 甲午之祖，名曰五冲。 甲午之父，三练六爻。 甲午之孙，曰卫上卿。 甲辰之祖，名曰三宁。 甲辰之父，罗列羽兵。 甲辰之孙，曰益非轻。 甲寅之祖！ 名带理非。 甲寅之父，秉金荷旎。 甲寅之孙，曰明文章。 在帝之庭，调理阴阳。 六十之子，造化维纲。 所居六官，祚运休祥。 正宫直符，前官六合。 左官太阴，后宫九地。 中宫勾陈，循环逆顺，上佐高真。 六十甲子，助成天德。 年建月建，日建时建。 期神立之，垂名遁典。 飞天法轮部 廓落高张，八卦分列。 刚柔磨荡，经纬不竭。 俯仰天地。 弥纶日月。 天斡地旋，始生丹元。 一气才通，上应天蓬。 运水於下，幽都玄宫亡壬癸乘位，变化无穷。 元气凝滞，闭塞而冬。 天道不备，上昏下蒙。 金至财结，木至则空。 水至勋冰，土至则崩。 火至财灭，神明莫通。 坎卦已陷，门生其中。 故名休门，阳气始布。 万物以萌，远行练卒。 事始取行，为无不利。 出逢阴人，紫碧之衣。 或见交争，若守高官。 乃迫乃凶，风尽气溃。 朱灵开昧，因他之利。 戊己生外，厚载之基。 上应天内，立秋物死。 日损之乡，金至则质。 木至则藏，水至则澄。 火至无光，土积为丘。 万物皇皇，地气不升。
chunks.translated_text:
At the dawn of primal separation, the Three Luminaries unfolded in radiance.
Within the Nine Mysteries, pure yang interwove in harmony.
The Eight Sceneries merged in darkness, giving rise to the Six Spirits.
Their light blazed in the Purple Void, while jade essence flowed in abundance.
The Dao divided and dispersed into forms—the sixty celestial stems.
The Five Phases congealed, illuminating the Nine Palaces.
Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth—transforming in duality.
Scattering their luminous spirits, one hundred and eighty in number.
Emerging from the profound, entering the subtle, penetrating the boundless.
Qi envelops Heaven and Earth; essence crowns the vastness of space.
They can separate, they can unite; they can be yin, they can be yang.
They can ascend, they can descend; they can die, they can live.
They can be, they can not-be; they can succeed, they can fail.
Without the Six Jia, the Three Lights would not shine.
Without the Six Jia, the Five Peaks would not form.
Without the Six Jia, humans could not preserve life.
When concealed and expounded, they become the root of the wondrous Dao.
Mastering this numinous power, the Six Directions unite in truth.
Their use aligns with Heaven and Earth—the gateway to the ten thousand methods.

The Six Qi flow in sequence, revolving through the Ten Heavens.
The Six Jia spread and circulate, traversing the hidden and obscure.
The ancestor of Jia-Zi is named Peach Tranquility.
The father of Jia-Zi is Union of Sceneries Wandering the Well.
The descendant of Jia-Zi is Wang Wenqing.
The ancestor of Jia-Xu is named Avoiding Directions.
The father of Jia-Xu is Myriad Layers of Blades.
The descendant of Jia-Xu is Zhan Zijiang.
The ancestor of Jia-Shen is named Upper Canopy Zhang.
The father of Jia-Shen is Three Assemblies of Dragon Essence.
The descendant of Jia-Shen is Hu Wenchang.
The ancestor of Jia-Wu is named Five Thrusts.
The father of Jia-Wu is Three Refinements and Six Lines.
The descendant of Jia-Wu is Wei Shangqing.
The ancestor of Jia-Chen is named Three Tranquilities.
The father of Jia-Chen is Arrayed Feathered Soldiers.
The descendant of Jia-Chen is Yi Feiqing.
The ancestor of Jia-Yin! Named Belt of Principle and Non-Principle.
The father of Jia-Yin holds metal and bears banners.
The descendant of Jia-Yin is Ming Wenzhang.
In the court of the Emperor, they regulate and harmonize yin and yang.
The sixty descendants form the warp and weft of creation.
Dwelling in the Six Palaces, they bestow fortune and auspicious omens.
The Central Palace’s Straight Talisman aligns with the Former Palace’s Six Harmonies.
The Left Palace’s Great Yin corresponds to the Rear Palace’s Nine Earths.
The Central Palace’s Hook Chen cycles in reversal and sequence,
assisting the lofty perfected.
The sixty Jia-Zi aid in completing Heaven’s virtue.
Year stems, month stems, day stems, hour stems—
the seasonal spirits establish them, bequeathing names to the concealed classics.

**Flying Heaven Dharma Wheel Section**
Vast and towering, the Eight Trigrams array in order.
Hard and soft grind and churn, their warp and weft inexhaustible.
They encompass Heaven and Earth in a single bow,
enveloping the sun and moon.
Heaven turns, Earth revolves—thus the cinnabar prime is born.
As soon as the qi connects, it responds above to Heavenly Soaring.
Water is set in motion below; in the Dark Capital’s Mysterious Palace,
Ren and Gui ascend their positions, transforming endlessly.
When primal qi congeals and stagnates, it seals in winter.
The Dao of Heaven is incomplete—above dim, below obscured.
When Metal arrives, wealth solidifies; when Wood arrives, it empties.
When Water arrives, merit freezes; when Earth arrives, it collapses.
When Fire arrives, wealth perishes—spiritual luminosity cannot commune.
The Kan trigram has already fallen; within its gate, life arises.
Thus it is named the Resting Gate, where yang qi first spreads.
The myriad things begin to sprout; distant journeys train soldiers.
Affairs commence and proceed—nothing is not favorable.
If you encounter a yin person clad in purple or green,
or witness conflict, hold to high office.
Yet if pressed, it turns inauspicious—wind exhausts, qi dissolves.
The Vermilion Spirit opens the obscure, relying on others’ advantage.
Wu and Ji generate externally, the foundation of Earth’s vast bearing.
Above, it responds to Heaven’s Interior; at the advent of autumn, things die.
In the realm of diminishing days, when Metal arrives, essence forms.
When Wood arrives, it hides; when Water arrives, it clarifies.
When Fire arrives, it loses light; when Earth accumulates, it becomes mounds.
The myriad things flourish—Earth’s qi does not ascend.

chunks.original_text: 门主其中，故名死门。 阴气盛焉，葬埋吊咳。 形戮追失，吉有所行。 中途异疾，出途患人，或闻哭泣。 运入坎宫，迫塞之凶。 气行乎震，兰台之宫。 雷藏雷垫，上应天冲。 春令方布，旸谷潜通。 甲乙来位，万药千红。 金至则缺，木至则森。 水至则润，火至则魂。 土至则阜，万有部分。 气运大通，门生其中。 故名伤门，得以理功。 大宜渔猎，杀伤有获。 若以言行，中逢盗贼。 出见火光，伐木取梁。 运入坤艮，迫则凶殃。 气接天霐，蓄风巽户。 春夏之交，上应天辅。 金至则伐，水至则墓。 火至则炎，土至则库。 木至则林，万该鼓舞。 发泄过中，门名曰杜。 杜者塞也，六阳绝数。 邀击诛逆，隐伏神助。 出逢男女，并行道路。 剔损手足，以应其玄。 又为吉事，如入昏雾。 运入艮坤，谋者必误。 中来□□，宫生黄庭。 五星齐耀，上应天禽。 上下无常，坤母而乘。 天□□□，灵府之兴。 为父之道，上应天心。 金刚为体，百灵已成。 金至则响，木至则荣。 火至则育，水至则清。 土至则巍，熟知其神。 高不可仰，低不可侵。 门生其中，故名开门。 阴气尽矣，变化之因。 远行得喜，大宜出军。 为无不就，酒食交迎。 出逢茶酒，或见贵人。 运至震巽，迫则虚名。 大化以彰，肃杀可惧。 尚书宫中，上应天柱。 庚辛之神，严令以布。 金至则光，木至则荒。 水至则涸，火至则亡。 土至则竭，万木焦黄。 天地不安，故名惊门。 吉事必危，凶事必贞。 战斗攻破，他危我存。 出逢害脚，眇目之人。 或闻恐怖，或见交争。 吉行中道，为吏所擒。 运至震巽，其祸立生。 天地失德，酷之大甚。 宫生玉房，上应天任。 阴阳回运，万有俱刑。 金至则朗，木至则萌。 水至则润，火至则温。 土至则穑，故得生成。 天道大同，故名生门。 于谋必获，谒贵得亲。 出逢巧艺，皂衣独行。 或见车马，紫黄衣人。 和气已播，不可杀生。 出征战敌，必犯天慎。 坎宫迫害，取渎幽冥。 挺立绛霄，南陵炎星。 纯阴交结，上应天英。 夏之为气，丙丁之精。 金至则冶，木至必焚。 水至则死，火至则兴。 土至则飞，万物熏蒸。 四方赫奕，故名景门。 上书遗赐，鏖战破围。 吉行中道，路必亡遗。 出逢乌噪，或有追呼。 又有酒食，见人赤须。 穷神知化，悔吝殊途。 九星八门，旺相之图。 鼓之雷霆，旺子之符。 润之风雨，相身之居。 日月相继，死父之模。 寒暑运行，囚鬼之户。 阴阳相薄，休妻为预。 动静有常，群分物聚。 逆之则灾，迫之则苦。 八卦已彰，八门同处。 吉凶荣辱，逐时为主。 万用皆知，非特军旅。 凡欲有为，兴衰是取。 旋斗历箕部 大哉九皇，喉舌天地。 变化九垓，各分其隶。 天蓬子禽，上归丹元，下守地玄。 保守长久，立国安边。 起造移徙，失火连绵。 嫁娶伤产，商贾逢冤。 出行军旅，春夏宜前。 秋冬莫往，难保回辕。 性主水火，盗贼之愆。 安坟立冢，却保万全。 此日之时，黑云霭天。 赤云大胜，青云莫先。 白云无功，黄云沛颠。 日奇乘之，搀抢凶源。 月奇乘之，伏龙不炊。 星奇乘之，文昌英鲜。 天内子成，上居朱灵，下守地阜。 交结受道，最得良助。 迁移筑室，大有迷误。 嫁娶讼修，秋冬益户。 大忌出军，军亡将□。 出行经商，分财散倡。
chunks.translated_text:
Within it lies the master—thus it is called the Death Gate.
Yin qi prevails here; burials, mournings, and lamentations abound.
Pursuit, execution, or loss—only auspicious journeys proceed.
Midway, strange illnesses arise; on the road, one suffers harm,
or hears the sound of weeping.
When the cycle enters the Kan Palace, pressing constriction brings misfortune.

Qi flows through Zhen, the Orchid Terrace’s abode.
Thunder conceals, thunder submerges—above, it responds to Heaven’s Collision.
As spring’s mandate spreads, the Valley of Sunlight lies hidden yet connected.
Jia and Yi arrive at their positions—myriad herbs, a thousand blooms.
When Metal arrives, it breaks; when Wood arrives, it flourishes.
When Water arrives, it moistens; when Fire arrives, it animates the soul.
When Earth arrives, it forms mounds—all things have their divisions.

The qi’s movement is greatly unobstructed; the gate arises within.
Thus it is called the Wound Gate, where governance and merit prevail.
Best suited for fishing and hunting—slaying yields bounty.
Yet in speech or action, one may encounter bandits midway.
On the road, firelight appears—felling trees to take beams.
When the cycle enters Kun or Gen, pressing brings calamitous misfortune.

Qi connects to Heaven’s Deluge, storing wind at Xun’s door.
At the cusp of spring and summer, above it responds to Heaven’s Aid.
When Metal arrives, it fells; when Water arrives, it buries.
When Fire arrives, it blazes; when Earth arrives, it stores.
When Wood arrives, it forms forests—all things dance in harmony.
But when release exceeds the mean, the gate is named the Closed Gate.
Closed means blocked—the six yang reach their absolute end.
Ambushing rebels, executing traitors—hidden spirits lend aid.
On the road, one meets men and women walking together.
Hands and feet are injured, aligning with its mystery.
Yet it may also bring fortune, like entering twilight mist.
When the cycle enters Gen or Kun, schemers are surely misled.

Within arises □□, the Yellow Court’s palace.
The Five Stars shine together—above, they respond to Heaven’s Bird.
Unfixed above and below, Earth Mother rides.
Heaven’s □□□ stirs the Spirit Treasury’s flourishing.
As the Way of the Father, above it responds to Heaven’s Heart.
With a body of adamantine, the hundred spirits are complete.
When Metal arrives, it resounds; when Wood arrives, it thrives.
When Fire arrives, it nurtures; when Water arrives, it purifies.
When Earth arrives, it towers—know well its spirit.
Too high to gaze upon, too low to encroach.
The gate arises within—thus it is called the Open Gate.
Yin qi is exhausted here, the cause of transformation.
Distant journeys bring joy; best to deploy troops.
Nothing fails to succeed—feasting and welcoming abound.
On the road, one meets tea or wine, or encounters a noble.
When the cycle reaches Zhen or Xun, pressing yields empty fame.
Great transformation manifests—stern killing is to be feared.
Within the Minister’s Palace, above it responds to Heaven’s Pillar.
The spirits of Geng and Xin issue strict decrees.
When Metal arrives, it gleams; when Wood arrives, it withers.
When Water arrives, it dries; when Fire arrives, it perishes.
When Earth arrives, it depletes—all trees wither and yellow.
Heaven and Earth are unsettled—thus it is called the Alarm Gate.
Auspicious affairs turn perilous; inauspicious ones prove steadfast.
In battle, the enemy is broken—others face danger while I endure.
On the road, one meets the lame or the one-eyed,
or hears terror, or witnesses conflict.
A journey midway turns auspicious, yet one is seized by officials.
When the cycle reaches Zhen or Xun, disaster strikes instantly.

Heaven and Earth lose virtue—cruelty reaches its extreme.
Within arises the Jade Chamber—above, it responds to Heaven’s Burden.
Yin and yang revolve—all things suffer punishment.
When Metal arrives, it shines; when Wood arrives, it sprouts.
When Water arrives, it moistens; when Fire arrives, it warms.
When Earth arrives, it reaps—thus life and completion are attained.
The Dao of Heaven is greatly harmonious—thus it is called the Life Gate.
In planning, one surely succeeds; seeking nobles, one gains intimacy.
On the road, one meets skilled artisans, or a lone traveler in black,
or sees carriages and horses, or a person in purple or yellow.
Harmonious qi spreads—killing must be avoided.
Deploying troops against enemies surely violates Heaven’s caution.
Pressing harm in the Kan Palace offends the dark and hidden.
Standing in the Crimson Empyrean, the Southern Mound’s fiery star.
Pure yin conjoins—above, it responds to Heaven’s Hero.
As summer’s qi, the essence of Bing and Ding.
When Metal arrives, it smelts; when Wood arrives, it burns.
When Water arrives, it dies; when Fire arrives, it flourishes.
When Earth arrives, it soars—all things steam and seethe.
The four directions blaze resplendently—thus it is called the Radiance Gate.
Submitting memorials brings rewards; in fierce battle, encirclements are broken.
A journey midway turns auspicious, yet the road surely brings loss.
On the road, one hears crows cawing, or is pursued and called,
or encounters feasting, or sees a red-bearded man.

Exhausting the spirit, knowing transformation—regret and shame diverge.
The nine stars and eight gates form the chart of prosperity and decline.
Drummed like thunder, the talisman of the prosperous child.
Moistened by wind and rain, the dwelling of the minister’s body.
Sun and moon follow one another, the model of the dead father.
Cold and heat circulate, the door of the imprisoned ghost.
Yin and yang press close—resting the wife is preparation.
Movement and stillness have constancy—groups divide, things gather.
To go against brings disaster; to press brings suffering.
The eight trigrams are manifest; the eight gates share a place.
Fortune and misfortune, honor and disgrace—time governs all.
All applications are known, not only for military campaigns.
For any endeavor, rise and fall are to be considered.

Revolving the Dipper, traversing the Winnowing Basket—
Great are the Nine Sovereigns, the throat and tongue of Heaven and Earth.
Transforming the nine realms, each divides its subordinates.
Tianpeng and Ziqin ascend to the Cinnabar Origin, below guard Earth’s Mystery.
Guard and preserve for long—establish the state, secure the frontier.
Construction and relocation—fire spreads unbroken.
Marriage and childbirth suffer harm; merchants encounter injustice.
For military campaigns and travel, spring and summer are favorable.
In autumn and winter, do not go—return is difficult to ensure.
Nature governs water and fire, the transgressions of bandits.
Establishing tombs and graves—yet all is preserved and secure.

At this day and hour, black clouds veil the sky.
Red clouds bring great victory; green clouds must not precede.
White clouds achieve nothing; yellow clouds bring torrential downpours.
If the Day Stem’s奇 (odd) rides it, seizing and plundering arise from misfortune.
If the Moon Stem’s奇 rides it, the hidden dragon does not cook.
If the Star Stem’s奇 rides it, literary brilliance shines.
Tiannei and Zicheng ascend to the Vermilion Spirit, below guard Earth’s Mounds.
Forming bonds, receiving the Dao—most excellent aid is gained.
Relocation and construction—great confusion and error arise.
Marriage, litigation, or repairs—autumn and winter increase the household.
Greatly avoid deploying troops—armies perish, generals □.
Traveling for trade—wealth disperses, companions scatter.

chunks.original_text: 口舌非理，八方塞杜。 此日之时，云生烟雾。 黑云则吉，白云难拒。 赤云盗侵，青云事悮。 日奇乘之，浮云蔽注。 月奇乘之，脱厄可去。 星奇乘之，解攻挫武。 天冲之翘，上居兰台，下守地苍。 行军伸耻，威耀八方。 破围攻敌，得以安康。 嫁娶产厄，伤败相妨。 上官移徙，死亡不臧。 祭杞商贾，离流他方。 此日之时，云气潜藏。 猛风激雷，四极飞扬。 日奇乘之，龙威得光。 月奇乘之，印绶永长。 星奇乘之，福禄繁昌。 天辅子卿，上居天霐，下守地刚。 行军大胜，万里雄强。 秋冬无功，可遏边疆。 移徙婚姻，春夏荣昌。 上官利武，起造尤良。 秋冬用之，盗贼凶殃。 商贾不利，筑室祯祥。 此日之时，天末云忙。 青云胜敌，赤云□□。 黑云亡败，白云彷徨。 日奇乘之，百战百长。 月奇乘之，五福悠长。 星奇乘之，冠带荣装。 天禽子公，上居黄庭，下享地龄。 祭□□□，断灭凶群。 行军四季，立爵边巡。 执仇讨贼，不战俱擒。 葬埋□□，五福来临。 上官文吉，移徙如心。 春夏之月，小挠来侵。 所为百事，无不丰荣。 此日之时，云气深沉。 日光晃朗，敌畏其名。 日奇乘之，双辅得人。 月奇乘之，日月踊轮。 星奇乘之，还同七珍。 天心子襄，上居灵府，下守地魁。 求灵治疾，不至徘徊。 行军战伐，得胜擒魁。 春夏不利，秋冬无灾。 迁移嫁娶，得遇梯媒。 筑室祠祀，惹起凶衰。 行船隐遁，称欲而回。 商贾起造，立见崩颓。 此日之时，云气崔鬼。 不可出战，动则锋摧。 天清朗然，万里通开。 日奇乘之，曜明九垓。 月奇乘之，试水探财。 星奇乘之，车驷迎来。 天柱子由，上居尚书，下守地晶。 大宜固守，勿可行军。 全师不返，将者哀声。 嫁娶离别，修造灾侵。 移徙商贾，百事不任。 私藏隐迹，却保安宁。 此日之时，云气如蒸。 青云丧乱，赤云兵临。 黑云奸至，黄云有惊。 日奇乘之，匿辜绝音。 月奇乘之，杜塞防擒。 星奇乘之，复荣而成。 天任子韦，上居玉房，下守地牡。 行军大胜，万里无阻。 嫁娶大倡，上官不武。 商筑修移，反招忧苦。 春夏尤宜，谒贵神助。 此偶之时，云生烟雾。 东西南北，八方得路。 不战用谋，敌人自惧。 日奇乘之，金玉如堵。 月奇乘之，重光入户。 星奇乘之，龙寿升举。 天英子房，上居绛云，下守地形。 远行舟楫，君子交迎。 出师败溃，商贾财空。 修造屋宇，失火重重。 上官祠祭，瘟疫来锺。 若言嫁娶，大有兴隆。 此日之时，赤气阴浓。 攻击退失，亦有狂风。 是为不吉，动则兵凶。 日奇乘之，雷奋天中。 月奇乘之，障翳英雄。 星奇乘之，御镞难通。 休囚乘之，出户呼从。 凡出天蓬，三称子公。 万神逊避，得以全功。 凡为将臣，切记心胸。 回度五常部 天道高邈，五常回度。 阴阳位分，干有十数。 甲为天福，开闱门户。 能知三甲，一开一杜。 不知三甲，六甲尽杜。 攻战行来，客兵神助。 赏功封爵，伏吟喜遇。 闻事并虚，冥谒及贾。 入宫有喜，移迁嫁娶。 不可行移，天庭不护。 六乙为直，往来恍惚。 日精相从，与时俱出。 行兵大胜，名曰天德。 攻者必权，杀者必获。 闻忧不忧，闻喜不喜。 移徙上官，商贾大利。 若行威刑，欺妄立至。 六丙为直，万兵莫往。 比若侯王，攻战毋赏。
chunks.translated_text:
Quarrels and disputes defy reason, blocking all eight directions.
At this day and hour, clouds arise in mist and haze.
Black clouds bring fortune; white clouds are hard to resist.
Red clouds invite bandit raids; green clouds bungle affairs.
If the Day Stem’s *qi* rides it, floating clouds obscure all.
If the Moon Stem’s *qi* rides it, one may escape calamity.
If the Star Stem’s *qi* rides it, attacks are repelled and might subdued.
Tianchong’s pinnacle ascends to Orchid Terrace, below guarding Earth’s Verdure.
Deploying troops avenges shame, power shining in all directions.
Breaking sieges and attacking foes brings peace and well-being.
Marriage, childbirth, or misfortune—harm and failure interfere.
Official transfers or relocations—death and misfortune abound.
Sacrifices, ancestral rites, or trade—separation and exile follow.

At this day and hour, cloud *qi* lies hidden.
Fierce winds and crashing thunder fly to the four extremes.
If the Day Stem’s *qi* rides it, the dragon’s might gains radiance.
If the Moon Stem’s *qi* rides it, seals and sashes endure forever.
If the Star Stem’s *qi* rides it, fortune and rank flourish abundantly.
Tianfu and Ziqing ascend to Heaven’s Deluge, below guarding Earth’s Firmness.
Deploying troops brings great victory, might spanning ten thousand *li*.
In autumn and winter, no gains—yet borders may be held.
Relocations and marriages—spring and summer bring prosperity.
Official promotions favor martial pursuits; construction is especially auspicious.
Using them in autumn and winter—bandits and misfortune arise.
Trade brings no profit; building dwellings brings good omens.

At this day and hour, clouds scurry at heaven’s edge.
Green clouds vanquish foes; red clouds □□.
Black clouds bring ruin; white clouds wander aimlessly.
If the Day Stem’s *qi* rides it, every battle is won.
If the Moon Stem’s *qi* rides it, the Five Fortunes stretch long.
If the Star Stem’s *qi* rides it, robes and sashes gleam with honor.
Tianqin and Zigong ascend to the Yellow Court, below enjoying Earth’s Longevity.
Sacrifices □□□ annihilate evil hordes.
Deploying troops in all four seasons—titles are bestowed, borders patrolled.
Seizing enemies and punishing bandits—without battle, all are captured.
Burials □□—the Five Fortunes arrive.
Official promotions favor civil affairs; relocations proceed as wished.
In spring and summer, minor disturbances intrude.
In all undertakings, nothing fails to flourish abundantly.

At this day and hour, cloud *qi* lies deep and still.
Sunlight shines bright; foes dread its name.
If the Day Stem’s *qi* rides it, dual aids are gained.
If the Moon Stem’s *qi* rides it, sun and moon leap like wheels.
If the Star Stem’s *qi* rides it, it equals the Seven Treasures.
Tianxin and Zixiang ascend to the Spirit Storehouse, below guarding Earth’s Chief.
Seeking spirits to cure illness—no hesitation remains.
Deploying troops or waging war—victory and capturing leaders follow.
Spring and summer bring no profit; autumn and winter incur no harm.
Relocations and marriages—favorable matchmakers appear.
Building dwellings or offering sacrifices—misfortune and decline arise.
Sailing ships or going into hiding—desires are fulfilled upon return.
Trade or construction—collapse is immediate.

At this day and hour, cloud *qi* looms towering.
Do not engage in battle—movement invites blade’s ruin.
Heaven clears and brightens, ten thousand *li* open.
If the Day Stem’s *qi* rides it, brilliance illuminates the Nine Realms.
If the Moon Stem’s *qi* rides it, testing waters reveals wealth.
If the Star Stem’s *qi* rides it, four-horse chariots arrive.
Tianzhu and Ziyou ascend to the Ministry of Works, below guarding Earth’s Crystal.
Best to hold fast—do not deploy troops.
Armies never return; generals wail in sorrow.
Marriages and partings, construction—disasters strike.
Relocations and trade—nothing succeeds.
Hiding in secret—peace and safety are preserved.

At this day and hour, cloud *qi* steams like vapor.
Green clouds bring chaos; red clouds bring troops.
Black clouds bring treachery; yellow clouds bring alarm.
If the Day Stem’s *qi* rides it, guilt is concealed and voices silenced.
If the Moon Stem’s *qi* rides it, blockades prevent capture.
If the Star Stem’s *qi* rides it, glory is restored and success achieved.
Tianren and Ziwei ascend to the Jade Chamber, below guarding Earth’s Gate.
Deploying troops brings great victory, unimpeded for ten thousand *li*.
Marriages and grand celebrations—officials avoid martial pursuits.
Trade and construction, relocations—misfortune and suffering follow.
Spring and summer are especially favorable; seeking noble spirits brings aid.

At this coinciding hour, clouds arise in mist and haze.
East, west, south, north—all eight directions find their way.
Without battle, using strategy—foes fear on their own.
If the Day Stem’s *qi* rides it, gold and jade stand like walls.
If the Moon Stem’s *qi* rides it, doubled light enters the household.
If the Star Stem’s *qi* rides it, dragon’s longevity ascends.
Tianying and Zifang ascend to Crimson Clouds, below guarding Earth’s Form.
Distant voyages by boat—noblemen welcome one another.
Deploying troops brings defeat and rout; trade empties coffers.
Building houses—fires strike repeatedly.
Official promotions and sacrifices—plagues descend.
Yet if marriage is spoken of—great prosperity arises.

At this day and hour, red *qi* thickens ominously.
Attacks and retreats fail; wild winds arise.
This is inauspicious—movement invites military disaster.
If the Day Stem’s *qi* rides it, thunder roars in heaven’s midst.
If the Moon Stem’s *qi* rides it, heroes are obscured.
If the Star Stem’s *qi* rides it, arrows cannot pass.
If the Restricted and Imprisoned ride it, stepping out invites clamor.
Whenever Tianpeng appears, thrice call out "Zigong."
All spirits yield and retreat—success is complete.
All generals and ministers must remember this in their hearts.

The Dao of Heaven is lofty and distant; the Five Constants revolve in cycles.
Yin and yang hold their positions; the *Gan* number ten.
*Jia* is Heaven’s blessing, opening gates and doors.
Knowing the Three *Jia*—one opens, one closes.
Not knowing the Three *Jia*—all six *Jia* are closed.
Attacking and marching—guest armies gain divine aid.
Rewarding merit and conferring titles—retreating brings joyous encounters.
Hearing rumors—all are false; secret visits and trade follow.
Entering the palace brings joy; relocations and marriages proceed.
Do not act or move—Heaven’s Court offers no protection.

*Yi* serves as the upright; comings and goings are elusive.
Sun’s essence follows, emerging with the hour.
Deploying troops brings great victory—this is called Heaven’s Virtue.
Attackers must seize power; killers must capture.
Hearing sorrow yet not grieving; hearing joy yet not rejoicing.
Relocations and official promotions, trade—great profit follows.
Yet if martial authority is wielded—deceit and falsehood arise immediately.

*Bing* serves as the upright—no armies dare advance.
Like a prince or king, in attack and battle, no rewards are given.

Greatly auspicious for deploying troops, gathering forces, and establishing camps.
The moon’s essence follows—receiving others’ deference and yielding.
Those entering the palace are promoted; market trade knows no bounds.
Hearing sorrow yet not grieving; hearing joy, one’s spirits soar.
Do not bestow private favors—this invites rebellion and treachery.
It is also called Heaven’s Might—all undertakings flourish.

*Ding* serves as the upright, emerging from darkness into obscurity.
Spirits and ghosts are hard to fathom; even at the brink of execution, no punishment falls.
Though a blade rests at the neck, one remains calm and unafraid.
Fugitives vanish near and far—none see their form.
Joy and sorrow are half absent; calamity stems from women.
Trade brings profit; promotions in office secure renown.
It is also called the Jade Maiden—do not deploy troops.

*Wu* serves as the upright, riding dragons for ten thousand miles.
The Dao bars no obstruction—greatly auspicious for distant campaigns.
No sorrow, only joy; promotions, trade, and minor gains follow.
It is also called Heaven’s Martial—misfortune and ruin are surely governed.

*Ji* serves as the upright, as if moved by spirits.
Unseen hook spirits bring hidden perils and misfortune.
Secret and private matters—nothing fails to succeed.
No joy, only sorrow; entering office brings promotion.
Marriages are half auspicious; trade yields half profit.
It is also called □□, illuminating old affairs.

*Geng* serves as the upright, walking as if embracing wood.
Those who forcefully venture forth will surely meet contention at the gate.
It is also called □□—matters often invite perverse obstacles.
When undertaking action, one is certain to suffer humiliation.
If one gains awareness, they will not embrace the three woods.
Not □□□, but bound and thrown into prison.
Hearing sorrow brings sorrow; hearing joy remains uncertain.
Firmly guarding the master’s □, □□ will surely be executed.
Marriages □□; market profits must shrink.
Grand campaigns of slaughter—this is called Heaven’s Lament.

*Xin* serves as the upright, encountering the dead while traveling.
Those who forcefully venture forth will be ensnared by punishment.
It is also called Heaven’s Court—walking through ruined walls.
If unaware, one’s body suffers torture.
Nets coil of their own accord; crimes bind one to the public court.
Deploying troops brings victory; joy and sorrow are balanced.
Entering office secures a position, though later promotions cease.
Trade yields no sales; marriages invite disaster.
Yet by upholding just laws, warnings and punishments may be averted.

*Ren* serves as the upright, restrained by officials.
Those who forcefully venture forth find no fortune arriving.
It is also called Heaven’s Prison—one must meet enemies and grievances.
No auspiciousness; officials will surely detain and delay.
Deploying troops brings victory; pursuing thieves leads to capture.
Entering office or relocating spans three counties and five prefectures.
Joy and sorrow are both absent; market profits are hard to reap.

*Gui* serves as the upright—none dare gaze upon them.
Unseen net spirits bring death upon stepping out the door.
It is also called Heaven’s Treasury—one may seek immortality.
Joy and sorrow are both absent; marriages bear no children.
Troops march without trace; entering office brings sudden promotion.
Relocating homes leads to hardship; trade comes to a halt.

The Heavenly Stems govern fate—fortune and misfortune depend on them.
Follow the auspicious and avoid the inauspicious—thus it is.

**Receiving the Precepts and Passing Through the Passes and Departments**
Officials wielding authority—eight gates are most excellent.
The Six Spirits govern them, aiding the yang with the yin.
In yang years, the Open Gate prevails, with □ as the master.
Starting from *Qian* Palace at *zi*, follow the Nine Heavens’ Hall.
In yin years, the Restriction Gate prevails, with the Hook Spirit as master.
Starting from *zi* in reverse, next to the Nine Earths’ Side.
The year determines the starting month; the month determines the stake.
From the first, proceed to whichever direction.
Observe the tortoise and purify the talismans—*Kan* Palace is auspicious.
Sitting at the Wounding Gate, one’s position will not last long.
When stars enter the inner heavens, it is especially inauspicious.
*Peng* and *ying* clash with the pillar—if activated, misfortune arises.
The Surprise Gate in *Kan*—time passes in vain.
One will surely incur delays, returning home after repeated trials.

**Lower Era**
*Dead Gate*　　　　　　*Open Gate*
*Great Yin*　　　　　　*True Yang* (for yang years)
