**Upper Era**
*Pillar* Gate　　　　　　*Life* Gate
*Gouchen*　　　　　　Nine Earths

In yin years, begin at *zi* and proceed in reverse. From the year, determine the first month; from the month, proceed to the first day. If it meets the *Open* Gate, one enjoys peace from beginning to end, favor and grace overflow, and an audience with the sovereign. If it meets the *Rest* Gate, myriad affairs flourish, governance earns praise, and the Nine Heavens resound with acclaim. If it meets the *Life* Gate, rule is achieved without force; the eight directions yield without contest, and the Nine Earths submit in harmony. If it meets the *Jing* Gate, one gains public recognition and recommendation, fame spreads through the Six Harmonies, and imperial summons descend like wings. If it meets the *Restriction* Gate, *Gouchen* ascends above; water, fire, bandits, and thieves require vigilant preparation and regulation. If it meets the *Dead* Gate, *Great Yin* descends below; commands lose their rectitude, and mourning arrives swiftly. The *Wounding* and *Surprise* Gates lie in the directions of sun and moon; if the day encounters these two omens, hasten to conceal oneself.

Whenever the day is auspicious, one must also seek a favorable hour. When stars and gates align propitiously, great achievement is assured. Any encounter with *bei*-comets or clashes hinders official advancement. If *fu*-symbols and affairs conflict, failure and misfortune arise at once. When three auspicious gates stand together, one attains lasting eminence.

**Battle and Combat Section**
For any engagement in battle, first examine the day and hour. In yang hours, raise drums, sound bells, and unfurl banners. In yin hours, lie in ambush to diminish the enemy’s might. If our forces are few, we remain secure; if theirs are many, they face peril. In sudden clashes, follow the gates and secure the auspicious. Standing at *Tianyi*, blades shatter for a thousand miles. Next, occupy the *Direct Affair* position, and the enemy will fear like thunder. Strike from behind the living, attack the dead—victory is certain.

When skies are overcast and rain falls heavily, the four directions grow dim. Without clepsydra, distinguishing hours becomes difficult; one must rely on the moving *shi*-diagram or observe the *qi*. When *Qi* Gates converge, this is known in *si*, *wu*, and *wei*. If the day’s general coincides with the *Qi* Gate, they share the same rank. There are also three victories: the method of standing firm, striking the *White Traitor*, and facing the *Heavenly Gate*. Also, turn away from the moon’s establishment and next from the *Life Spirit*. When two stars enter one another, the *Horse* position vanishes. If all four directions scatter, security cannot be assured even at dawn or dusk. When *fu*-symbols align with *White*, the army suffers great loss. Under *Great Punishment* or *Flying*, chariots and horses are damaged and lost. When the Nine Stars weaken, defeat saps the soul.

Above the Nine Heavens, one may grandly display might. Below the Nine Earths, one may guard encampments. In the palace of *Great Yin*, concealment is as if divine. In the palace of the *Six Harmonies*, secret plans are stealthily executed. Great inauspiciousness and great slaughter occur when the palace is violated by *Gouchen*. *Jia* and *bing* interact, embodying the numen of power and virtue. The upper five are yang dwellings; the lower three are auspicious stars. If *Qi* Gates are not oppressed and star positions do not clash, applying these four principles ensures all affairs will be at peace.

When the hour’s stem overcomes the day, generals and lords gain hollow reputations. In marching armies or deploying formations, defeat and ruin follow. At rest, obscurity prevails; in action, no glory is won. When *bing* aligns with the *Dead* Gate, rebellion and chaos take shape. When *Dead* aligns with *bing*-auspicious, formations dissolve in chaos. When *bing* aligns with the *Wounding* Gate, battle brings ruin. When *Wounding* aligns with *bing*-auspicious, internal strife erupts. When *yi* aligns with the *Dead* Gate, encampments stand empty. When *Dead* aligns with *yi*-auspicious, weapons are lost. When *yi* aligns with the *Wounding* Gate, attacks must not be launched. When *Wounding* aligns with *yi*-auspicious, defeat is beyond recovery. If such configurations appear, the general must be cautious. Do not engage an advancing enemy; do not pursue a retreating one.

I impart to you one method: sever a peach branch from the shade, inscribe a talisman on its bark, and tread upon the *Dou*-ladle’s handle. Transform grasses and trees into soldiers to bolster our military might. Contend for mountains and seize strategic points to break enemy encirclements. Like casting a flaw at an egg, act in accord with the celestial patterns. Yet do not indulge in wanton slaughter, lest you incur delays. I admonish you, O accomplished general: rectify your heart and do not stray.

**Karmic Destiny and Human Relations Section**
Human bonds and marriages follow the diagrams of yin and yang. The *Zhoutang* and *Heavenly Auspice* take *East Zhen* as their model. In months with many days, begin at *Kan* and proceed to *Gen*’s door. In months with few days, begin at *Dui* and proceed in reverse to *Kun*’s corner. Entering *Xun* harms the father-in-law; entering *Gen* replaces the mother-in-law. Entering *Gao* wounds the elder brother; entering *Kan* overcomes the husband. Entering *Dui* kills the wife; entering *Qian* brings no misfortune. In the positions of *Qian*, *Kun*, and *Zhen*, blessings gather at the gate. When yin and yang have generals, stems and branches clash. The yin general kills the wife; the yang general kills the husband. When yin and yang lack generals, they align with the celestial tally.

Before the monthly taboo, take the heavenly stem; after the taboo, take the next branch for support. If stem and branch harmonize with the month, the absence of a general serves as elimination. Though the great method is thus, it does not yet align with the classics. To avoid disaster, first examine the Nine Stars. The Nine Palaces they govern divide fortune and misfortune distinctly. First determine *Tianpeng*, then take *Tianying*. The natures of water and fire bring only calamity.

The first palace is *Kan*; the second palace is *Kun*. One elder brother and two daughters—this is the present life’s fate. If the gate spirit is inauspicious, parents do not survive. Three wives are killed, and after parting, remarriage follows. When fate enters the *Zhen* palace, children are overcome entirely. If the gate is auspicious, one daughter remains, but the son becomes a disabled person. When fate enters the *Xun* palace, two pairs of children are born. If all are yang, half survive; if all are yin, the line is cut off. Adopting another surname, one must seek an outsider as heir. When fate enters the *Qian* palace, two chambers of children are born. Six sons are reared, three yin and three yang. Daughters are older, sons younger—thus one attains prominence. When fate enters the *Dui* palace, husband and wife do not clash. Four sons and three daughters ensure a peaceful life. When fate enters the *Gen* palace, parents part in life. The wife conceives no children; much loss and weariness follow. When fate enters the *Gao* palace, household and dwelling are not at peace. Abandoning ancestral legacy, many children and grandchildren arise. In later years, one son dissipates the family estate. One daughter brings sorrow; one son attains nobility.

Next are *Tianren*, *Tiannei*, and *Tianqin*. These three stars serve as envoys, their natures ever deep. When fate enters the *Kan* palace, two sons are born. When three yang disasters arrive, the mother falls ill and the son is separated. When fate enters the *Kun* palace, household and dwelling remain unclear.

**Burial Methods**

Burial methods rely on the harmony of stems and branches with the numinous. On days of *Jia* and *Geng*, align with *Shen* and *Yin*. On days of *Bing* and *Ren*, align with *Chen*, *Wu*, and *Shen*. On days of the six *Ji*, align with *Wei* and *You*. On days of the six *Wu*, the *Dunjia* method is unheard of. For *Yi*, *Xin*, *Ding*, and *Gui*, align with *You* and pair accordingly.

The jade dog barks loudly, the golden rooster crows alone. The earthly tiger does not feed—thus may a thousand springs be preserved. On such days, the mountain’s orientation must accord with the *Qimen*. Below, it connects with earthly stars; above, it aligns with celestial bodies. The sitting mountain and burial site determine fortune or misfortune in advance.

*Yu* corresponds to *Lianzhen*, *Gong* to *Wenqu*, *Zheng* to *Pojun*, *Jiao* to *Jumen*, *Shang* to *Tanlang*—arising from the central courtyard. Next, they fly forth to *Qian*, with *Kan* and *Dui* as neighbors. If *Wenqu* is offended, the household will not prosper. Men wander from their homeland; women become licentious. If *Pojun* is offended, illness and lawsuits never cease. The eldest daughter kills her husband; the eldest son suffers execution. If *Lucun* is offended, descendants die young, hunchbacked and blind. If *Lianzhen* is offended, official troubles entangle, father and son part, and violent death strikes elsewhere.

*Tanlang*, *Wuqu*, *Fubi*, and *Jumen* bring official promotions and treasures, filling the household with blessings. If even one star is present, fame and profit soar. At the time of interment, the nine stars must also be fixed. *Qin Xin* clashes with the auspicious; next is *Fu* and *Tian Ren*. *Simen* conceals the extraordinary, as does *Kaimen*. Within a hundred days of burial, myriad fortunes arrive.

Sever the earthly door, erase the roots of death. Heaven and earth are fixed, and all states conceal their forms. The seven malevolent *Ci Xiong Sha* call to their neighbors. Triple the stakes against the three *Sha*, the *Tai Sui*, and all gods. How dare the host of evils dare to approach? Avoid startling *Shang*, harming *Du*, or disturbing *Jing*, *Xiu*, and *Sheng*. Worship the five without encounter, for the gate presses upon the ritual. The three wonders enter the tomb—*Fanfu* and *Fuyin*. *Kan* responds in one year, *Kun* in two springs. The nine palaces bring nine years of calamity. To discern the new and old, the burial site’s orientation holds no difficulty. Gather the mysteries and know without climbing.

chunks.original_text: 天机探惜，智在克宽。 玄精碧匣灵宝聚玄经卷中竟 玄精碧匣灵宝聚玄经卷下 天地山泽部 天地定位，阴阳分离。 图书出数，支干纪时。 八卦成立，九宫相随。 悔吝有兆，存亡预知。 干名遁甲，支曰六壬。 一亏一盈，变化高低。 独用六壬，星门干缺。 如用遁甲，神杀支亏。 支干不备，吉凶奚为。 深虑后世，无能广规。 止以先锋，言识情微。 次将统体，罔察兴衰。 末於尽势，决其安危。 神将休旺，仍辩尊卑。 造化强弱，吉凶可期。 此乃皮肤，不尽根蒂。 天地枢机，有道可窥。 总曰壬遁，察见毫厘。 聪明贤哲，故能一之。 欲为万事，首出三奇。 先锋助之，各有其宜。 旺相在门，喜气怡怡。 权利两遂，行逢忻嬉。 日禄在门，君子提携。 酒食财谷，动静欢归。 日马在门，图干碌碌。 公私失望，返覆奔驰。 日合在门，阴人助力。 阴谋成就，贵人相依。 若逢恶将，未免生疑。 日破在门，口舌难会。 结交丧约，口许心违。 日劫在门，盗贼失脱。 争官难理，财化尘飞。 日鬼在门，病者难医。 若谋他事，是反成非。 日墓在门，水陆倾危。 尤防血光，蔽翳徘徊。 空亡在门，不宜主事。 反招谤讪，哄哄虚雷。 天乙在门，贵人应之。 行逢良善，长者趋陪。 腾蛇在门，怪异惊吓。 若值风雨，中道空回。 若闻鸦呜，追捕交加。 朱雀在门，红物前奢。 闻得乐音，或见图画。 小有口舌，事谋有差。 六合在门，车马闹闻。 阴人聚欢，彩色衣华。 青龙在门，财气重加。 道逢吏人，或见奇花。 勾陈在门，人物争斗。 百难相逐，□□□□。 天空在门，贱物拥道。 多有成败，秽语喧哗。 白虎在门，迭见官非。 闻悲见死，轿马兵车。 太常在门，见闻异事。 巧绘神□，□□□□。 玄武在门，阴云黯黯。 惊惶亡失，雨横风斜。 太阴在门，贤妇异常。 小求大得，老妇进茶。 天后在门，弱而得就。 婴童戏嬉，女子还家。 奇门先兆，应之无差。 立春之日，厥时至良。 岁中休否，可得寻详。 直符布位，直事分乡。 天干为使，循落何方。 开门定水，怕逢玄武。 从魁相附，干月滔洋。 神后白虎，四时茫茫。 惊门定贼，太冲蛇武。 劫杀日鬼，盗贼猖狂。 天空太乙，搅扰四方。 传送朱雀，声势扬扬。 加之日墓，万姓惶惶。 如见勾神，贼自潜藏。 不宜白虎，雄勇难当。 太平气象，门立大常。 景门定火，胜光太乙。 腾蛇朱雀，斯为火殃。 不宜太冲，功曹来傍。 传送六合，刑害相伤。 次分分野，丁丙之乡。 月厌同住，火烛堤防。 死门主灾，不可来巽。 大吉小吉，风灾不祥。 功曹青龙，春多霖雨。 太乙朱雀，夏热炎长。 传送太阴，秋多寒凉。 登明天后，冬极严霜。 胜光胜蛇，人染瘟黄。 天刚白虎，百物相伤。 从魁勾陈，岚瘴村坊。 天刚从魁？ 六庚加己。 壬癸太乙，震动山岗。 休门主雨，风神白虎。 更有青龙，逐节而取。 以干纳支，大吉加祥。 太冲神后，河魁从魁，四神下辰，主之降雨。 日马逢龙，必生水苦。 雨中发风，必有白虎。 米麦司神，伤门与生。 三奇之下，与禄为乡。 太常丰稔，功曹岁亨。 贵人在治，斗米百文。 后合鬼神，□□□□。 旱天有方，考之杜门。 魁罡蛇虎，不可同存。 太冲下□，□□□□。 若同火将，火神同名。 加之月厌，五谷难成。 天火地焦，□□□□。

When the Six Rites strike punishment, Vermilion Bird and Hook Star appear. One seals their mouth and utters no words, yet invites many accusations. If further paired with Day Breaker, dogs bite travelers. When the Three Marvels enter the tomb, beware of *Dengming*. Documents reverse, and affairs are met with hesitation. When Heavenly Stem and River Chariot appear, darkness turns to light. If the Noble One is in governance, prison matters resolve smoothly. When White Tiger and Soaring Serpent appear, loss and mourning bring sorrow. Travelers come and go, affairs multiply like hemp. When Great Surge and Six Harmonies appear, travelers return home. When Great Unity and White Tiger appear, women turn lewd and wicked. When Merit Officer and Heavenly Consort appear, with Great Yin and *Congkui*, young monks visit the door, and Daoist priests offer tea. When Vermilion Bird and Soaring Serpent appear, poisoned food is lamentable. When *Dengming* and Divine Marshal appear, their schemes [remain unclear].

When Merit Officer and Later Harmony appear, crimes lead to beheading. When Great Surge sinks ships, *Congkui* hangs heads. When Great Constancy does not die, one suffers broken limbs.
